Requirements: To be considered for admission, first-time freshmen must submit an application for admission, a $35 non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. UNA is currently Test-Optional for students who have a 3.0 or higher high school GPA. Students with a GPA below a 3.0 must submit test scores for admission consideration.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: Political science is the systematic study of governments, public policies, political processes, and political behavior. It is a broad field, encompassing a variety of subfields including American politics, comparative politics, international relations, political theory, and public law. The Political Science program at UNA provides students with a comprehensive understanding of these areas, preparing them for careers in government, law, non-profit organizations, education, and journalism, as well as for graduate study. Our curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and effective communication, essential tools for success in any field. Students will learn how to analyze political issues, evaluate policy proposals, and engage in informed civic participation. The program fosters a deep appreciation for democratic values and institutions, and encourages students to become active and responsible citizens.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Political Science
EnglishScore: International students must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be met through various options, including: a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 61 (or 500 on the PBT), a minimum IELTS score of 5.5, a minimum PTE score of 46, a minimum Duolingo score of 95, or completion of ELS Language Centers Level 109.
Requirements: The University of North Alabama is test-optional for admission. Applicants can be admitted via two pathways: 1) Traditional admissions with a minimum 2.25 high school GPA and a minimum 18 ACT composite or 960 SAT total score. 2) Test-optional admissions with a minimum 2.50 high school GPA. Required documents include the application for admission, application fee, and an official high school transcript.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering

ProgramName: Bachelor_of_Arts in Psychology
EnglishScore: Evidence of English proficiency is required for all applicants from countries where English is not the native language. This can be demonstrated by meeting one of the following: Official TOEFL score of at least 61 (internet based test), Official IELTS score of at least 5.5, Official PTE score of 46, Official Duolingo score of 90, or successful completion of the ELS Language Centers Intensive Program Level 112.
Requirements:
The University of North Alabama has a test-optional admission policy for first-time freshmen through Fall 2025. Applicants with a high school GPA of 2.5 or higher are not required to submit test scores. Applicants with a GPA between 2.0 and 2.49 must submit a test score.

Unconditional Admission:
Requires either a minimum composite score of 18 on the ACT (or 960 on the SAT) with a minimum 2.00 high school GPA, OR a minimum high school GPA of 2.25 with six completed semesters. An official high school transcript is required.

Conditional Admission:
Requires a minimum high school GPA of 2.00 and a composite score of 16 or 17 on the ACT (or 880-950 on the SAT).
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: Psychology is a science that strives to understand human and animal behavior. Students majoring in psychology at UNA will gain knowledge of several areas of psychology, including abnormal, developmental, cognitive, social, and experimental psychology. Students will learn how to analyze and interpret psychological data, write research papers, and present psychological findings. The Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree requires 120 credit hours and a minor (18 hours) outside the department.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Psychology
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be met by providing an official score report for one of the following: TOEFL (61 iBT or 500 PBT), IELTS (5.5), PTE Academic (46), Duolingo English Test (95), or completion of Level 112 of the ELS Language Centers' English for Academic Purposes Program.
Requirements:
Unconditional Admission: High school GPA of 2.25 or higher. A high school diploma with a minimum of 24 credits.
Conditional Admission: High school GPA of 2.00-2.24. A high school diploma with a minimum of 24 credits.
UNA is test-optional for students with a high school GPA of 2.50 or higher. Students with a GPA between 2.0 and 2.49 will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. Students with a GPA below 2.0 may be admissible with an ACT score of 18 or higher or a SAT score of 940 or higher.
Department: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Psychology provides students with a broad and rigorous exposure to the science of behavior and mental processes. Through coursework, research opportunities, and practicum experiences, students develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills applicable to various careers and graduate programs. Graduates are prepared for entry-level positions in human services, research, and business, or for advanced study in psychology or related fields such as counseling, social work, and law.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with academic scholarships ranging from $4,000 to $10,000 per year. Some scholarships cover full tuition.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Recreation
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate proficiency in English by one of the following methods: Minimum score of 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT) or 500 on the paper-based test (PBT); IELTS: Minimum score of 5.5; PTE (Academic): Minimum score of 46; Duolingo: Minimum score of 95; ELS: Successful completion of Level 112 of the ELS English Language Center's Intensive English Program.
Requirements:
First-time freshmen must submit an official high school transcript. Applicants who graduated from high school within the last three years have two admission pathways:
1) Traditional Admission: Submit an official high school transcript and an ACT/SAT score.
2) Test Optional Admission: Students with a 3.00 high school GPA or higher who do not wish to have their test scores considered must complete the essay portion of the admissions application.

Unconditional admission requires a minimum 2.25 high school GPA and a minimum 18 ACT or 940 SAT score.
Conditional admission requires a minimum 2.00 high school GPA and a minimum 16 ACT or 860 SAT score.
Department: The College of Education and Human Sciences
Fees: In-State: $4,260 per semester (12-18 credit hours); Out-of-State: $8,520 per semester (12-18 credit hours)
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Recreation program focuses on preparing students to become recreation professionals in a variety of settings. Students will develop skills in program planning, leadership, administration, and evaluation. The curriculum emphasizes experiential learning and practical application, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to meet the dynamic needs of the recreation and leisure industry. Graduates are prepared for careers in parks and recreation, community recreation, therapeutic recreation, outdoor recreation, and commercial recreation.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Social Work
EnglishScore: Students whose native language is not English must provide evidence of proficiency in the English language. This may be done by submitting one of the following: A minimum score of 500 on the paper-based TOEFL (PBT), 173 on the computer-based TOEFL (CBT), 61 on the internet-based TOEFL (iBT), 5.5 on the IELTS, 46 on the PTE Academic, 95 on the Duolingo English Test (DET), or Proof of completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center in the United States. Several other exemptions are also listed, such as graduation from a high school in the United States.
Requirements: Admission to the BSW Program is a selective process and must occur prior to a student's enrollment in any 400-level social work course. Students who meet the minimum criteria are not guaranteed admission to the program. The social work program admission criteria include: 1. Submission of a formal, written application to the BSW Program. 2. Completion of SW 230 and SW 235 with a grade of 'C' or higher. 3. Completion of at least 45 credit hours. 4. A cumulative GPA of at least 2.5. 5. Recommendation for admission by the Social Work Admissions Committee based on consideration of the completed application portfolio, which includes the formal application, the student’s academic record, a personal statement, and letters of recommendation.
Department: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) program, housed in the Department of Sociology and Social Work, is designed to prepare students for generalist social work practice and for graduate study in social work. It provides students with a broad knowledge base of social work practice in a wide variety of settings. Students completing the BSW program receive a professional degree that provides a beginning level for professional employment and for entry into graduate schools of social work. The UNA BSW Program is accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE). The social work profession promotes social justice and social change with diverse populations in the pursuit of enhancing human well-being. It is founded on a core of professional values and ethics. The social work program at UNA uses experiential learning and faculty expertise to prepare students for the challenges and rewards of this profession. The curriculum includes course work in human behavior, social work practice, social welfare policy, research, and field education. The program’s mission is to prepare generalist social work students with the knowledge, values, and skills to work effectively with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities and to practice ethically in a diverse and complex world.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Sociology (Family Life Education)
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency by submitting one of the following: TOEFL score of at least 500 on the paper-based test or 61 on the internet-based test; IELTS score of at least 5.5; PTE score of at least 46; Duolingo score of at least 95; or Completion of the ELS Language Center’s intensive program, level 112.
Requirements: The University of North Alabama practices a test-optional admission policy. Freshman applicants who have a 2.25 cumulative high school GPA or greater on a 4.0 scale will be granted unconditional admission. Applicants who have a cumulative high school GPA between a 2.0-2.24 on a 4.0 scale will be granted conditional admission. For students who choose to submit test scores, an 18 ACT composite or 960 SAT total score is required in addition to the GPA requirement.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description:
The Sociology program at UNA provides students with a broad and systematic study of society and human behavior. Sociology is the scientific study of the development, structure, interaction, and collective behavior of organized groups of human beings. Sociologists examine social factors, social change, and the social effects of human behavior. Sociology students analyze why and how people interact in social systems using both quantitative and qualitative techniques, while learning research, writing, critical thinking, and communication skills.
The Family Life Education concentration is designed to prepare students for careers in social service agencies, family support programs, and related fields. It also provides a strong foundation for graduate studies in marriage and family therapy, social work, counseling, and related areas. Students learn about family dynamics, child development, interpersonal relationships, and community resources. The curriculum emphasizes practical skills in program planning, evaluation, and client interaction.
Accredidation: Approved by the National Council on Family Relations (NCFR) as meeting the standards for the Provisional Certified Family Life Educator (CFLE) designation.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to Full Tuition, Fees, Room, and Board

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Sociology (Family Life Education)
EnglishScore: An international applicant must meet the same academic standards for admission as a native student. In addition, the student must demonstrate proficiency in the English language. One of the following may be submitted as proof of proficiency: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) with a minimum score of 500 (paper-based) or 173 (computer-based) or 61 (Internet-based); International English Language Testing System (IELTS) with a band score of 5.5; Pearson Test of English Academic (PTE) with a score of 46; or Duolingo with a score of 95. Other proof of proficiency options include completion of ELS Level 112 or successful completion of the UNA English as a Second Language Program.
Requirements: Unconditional Admission of First-Time Freshmen: Applicants who have a high school diploma or GED and meet the following criteria will be admitted unconditionally: 1. A minimum composite score of 18 on the ACT (or 940 on the SAT) and a minimum of a 2.0 high school GPA. OR 2. As a test-optional university, students with a minimum of a 2.25 GPA are not required to submit ACT/SAT scores.
Department: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Family Life Education concentration leads to a Bachelor of Science degree. This concentration prepares students for careers in family life education, human services, and other professions related to family and community well-being. The curriculum is designed to meet the academic requirements for provisional certification as a Family Life Educator by the National Council on Family Relations (NCFR).
Accredidation: The curriculum is designed to meet the academic requirements for provisional certification as a Family Life Educator by the National Council on Family Relations (NCFR).
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; e.g., Academic Scholarships up to $3,000/year, Excellence Scholarships from $4,000 to $9,000/year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Sport and Recreation Management
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-English speaking countries must submit proof of English proficiency. This can be accomplished by submitting an official score report from one of the following: TOEFL iBT minimum score of 61, IELTS minimum score of 5.5, Duolingo minimum score of 90, PTE minimum score of 46, or ELS completion of level 112.
Requirements: UNA has a test-optional admission policy. Freshman applicants for admission must have a minimum high school GPA of 2.25. Students must meet at least one of the following criteria for unconditional admission to UNA: High school GPA of 2.50 or higher and an ACT composite score of 18 or higher (or SAT equivalent). OR High school GPA of 2.75 or higher. OR High school GPA of 2.25 or higher and an ACT composite score of 20 or higher (or SAT equivalent).
Department: Anderson College of Nursing and Health Professions
Description: The Sport and Recreation Management program in the Department of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation is committed to preparing students for successful careers in the sport and recreation industry. The curriculum focuses on developing knowledge and skills in areas such as sport marketing, facility management, event planning, finance, legal aspects of sport, and human resource management. Students gain practical experience through internships and field experiences, allowing them to apply classroom learning in real-world settings. The program emphasizes ethical leadership, critical thinking, and effective communication, preparing graduates to manage and lead various sport and recreation organizations. Career opportunities include positions in professional and collegiate sports, community recreation, event management, health and fitness clubs, and sports marketing firms.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Sustainability
EnglishScore: An official score report is required from one of the following testing agencies: TOEFL: 61 iBT (internet-based) or 500 PBT (paper-based); IELTS: 5.5; PTE: 46; Duolingo: 90; ELS Language Center: Completion of Level 109.
Requirements:
Admission to the University of North Alabama is based on a comprehensive review of each applicant's academic record. UNA practices test optional admissions. ACT/SAT scores will not be required for admissions consideration, scholarship review or for course placement. Students may choose to submit their test score as part of the admissions process. Students who meet the following criteria will be admitted to the university:

Unconditional Admission (With Test Score):
- Minimum 2.0 cumulative high school GPA on a 4.0 scale AND
- Minimum 18 ACT composite score or 940 SAT total score

Unconditional Admission (Without Test Score - Test Optional):
- Minimum 2.25 cumulative high school GPA on a 4.0 scale
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Sustainability provides students with the opportunity to pursue an interdisciplinary degree that explores the interdependent relationship between humans and the natural environment. Students will be introduced to issues that impact local, regional, and global sustainability efforts. The program emphasizes a holistic understanding of how environmental, economic, and social systems interact and influence each other. Students will develop critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and ethical awareness to address complex sustainability challenges. The curriculum integrates knowledge from various disciplines, including environmental science, economics, political science, sociology, and ethics. Through coursework, research opportunities, and experiential learning, students will gain the expertise to contribute to sustainable development initiatives in diverse professional settings. Graduates will be prepared for careers in environmental management, urban planning, corporate social responsibility, policy analysis, non-profit advocacy, and further graduate studies in sustainability-related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Sustainability
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-English speaking countries must submit one of the following: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) with a minimum score of 500 on the paper-based test (PBT) or 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT). IELTS (International English Language Testing System) with a minimum score of 5.5. PTE (Pearson Test of English) Academic with a minimum score of 46. Duolingo with a minimum score of 95. ELS Language Center Level 112 with a certificate of completion.
Department: School of Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Sustainability degree focuses on the interdisciplinary scientific and social aspects of sustainability. It provides students with the critical thinking and analytical skills to understand complex environmental, social, and economic issues and to develop innovative solutions for a sustainable future. The curriculum integrates knowledge from various fields, including environmental science, economics, sociology, political science, and ethics, to equip students with a holistic understanding of sustainability challenges and opportunities. Graduates will be prepared for careers in government agencies, non-profit organizations, and private industries, working to address sustainability issues at local, regional, and global scales, or to pursue graduate studies in sustainability or related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Visual Arts and Design
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency by one of the following methods: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) minimum score of 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT); International English Language Testing System (IELTS) minimum score of 5.5; Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic minimum score of 46; Duolingo minimum score of 95; Successful completion of the English Language Services (ELS) Language Centers’ Level 112.
Requirements:
To be admitted to the university as a freshman, applicants must submit an application, a non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. The University of North Alabama has a test-optional admission policy for students with a 2.25 or higher high school GPA.

Specific to the B.F.A. program: Admission into the B.F.A. program requires submission and approval of a portfolio of the student’s work during the student’s sophomore year after completion of the Art and Design Foundation courses.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) program is a professional degree in Visual Arts and Design that provides comprehensive training in various art disciplines and prepares students for careers in art, design, and related fields or for graduate study. This program focuses on developing advanced skills, critical thinking, and a professional portfolio through rigorous studio practice, art history, and theoretical studies. Students gain an in-depth understanding of artistic principles, techniques, and contemporary issues, fostering creative expression and innovative problem-solving.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Visual Arts and Design
EnglishScore: All students from non-English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency by one of the following: a minimum TOEFL score of 500 (PBT) or 61 (iBT), a minimum IELTS score of 5.5, a minimum PTE Academic score of 46, a minimum Duolingo English Test (DET) score of 95, or successful completion of Level 112 in the ELS Language Centers Intensive Program.
Requirements: To apply for freshman admission, prospective students must submit an application for admission, pay the $35 application fee, and submit an official high school transcript. The University of North Alabama is test-optional through Fall 2025, and standardized test scores (ACT/SAT) are not required for admission. For students who submit scores, unconditional admission may be granted with a minimum 2.25 high school GPA and a minimum 18 ACT composite (970 SAT ERW + M), or a minimum 2.50 high school GPA and a minimum 16 ACT composite (880 SAT ERW + M).
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Visual Arts and Design provides students with a broad and comprehensive education in the visual arts, preparing them for a wide range of careers and further academic pursuits. This program offers a strong foundation in art history, theory, and practice, emphasizing critical thinking, creativity, and problem-solving skills. Students in the BA program will explore various artistic disciplines, including drawing, painting, sculpture, printmaking, photography, digital art, and graphic design. The curriculum is designed to foster both technical proficiency and conceptual understanding, allowing students to develop a distinctive artistic voice. Upon graduation, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to pursue careers in areas such as art education, gallery management, museum studies, graphic design, illustration, web design, and other creative industries. The program also serves as excellent preparation for graduate studies in art and related fields.
Accredidation: The Department of Art and Design is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $2,000 to full tuition

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Visual Arts and Design
EnglishScore: All undergraduate students applying as F-1 or J-1 students must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be met by providing an official score report showing a minimum TOEFL score of 500 on the paper-based test (PBT) or 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT); a minimum IELTS score of 5.5; a minimum PTE Academic score of 46; or a Duolingo score of 95. Completion of ELS Language Center's Level 112 also fulfills this requirement.
Requirements: The University of North Alabama has adopted a test-optional admission policy for first-time freshmen. Students may be admitted based on the traditional method or the test-optional method. For traditional admission, a student must have a minimum 2.0 high school GPA and a minimum 18 ACT or 960 SAT composite score. For test-optional admission, a student must have a minimum 2.5 high school GPA.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Concentration: Art History, Digital Art, Graphic Design, Photography, Painting, Printmaking, and Sculpture
Description:
The Department of Art and Design offers two bachelor’s degree programs. The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Visual Arts & Design offers concentrations in: Art History, Digital Art, Graphic Design, Photography, Painting, Printmaking, and Sculpture. The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Studio Art is a professional degree in art with a focus in painting, printmaking, and sculpture. Both programs prepare students for advanced study in their respective fields or for careers in the visual arts and design.

The B.S. in Visual Arts & Design is ideal for students who wish to pursue a career in one of the many Visual Arts and Design fields. Through extensive instruction, critiques, and an internship, students develop both practical and conceptual skills. The internship provides the opportunity for students to apply their skills in real-world situations, thus gaining valuable professional experience.

The B.S. in Visual Arts and Design provides students with a broad and inclusive view of Visual Arts and Design and prepares students to:
- Demonstrate knowledge of the historical, theoretical, and cultural context of visual arts and design.
- Demonstrate proficiency in relevant techniques, technologies, and methodologies in their chosen concentration.
- Critically analyze, interpret, and evaluate visual information.
- Effectively communicate visual ideas and concepts through a variety of media.
- Develop a professional portfolio demonstrating a strong understanding of visual arts and design principles and practices.
Accredidation: The Department of Art and Design is an institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).
CostPerCredit: $443 per credit hour (In-state); $886 per credit hour (Out-of-state)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Biology (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: International applicants must provide proof of English proficiency by one of the following: TOEFL score of 61 iBT or 500 PBT; IELTS score of 5.5; Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic score of 46; Duolingo English Test score of 90; ELS Language Center completion of Level 109; or other approved methods like completion of UNA's Intensive English Program or being a native English speaker from an approved country.
Requirements:
Initial admission to the University of North Alabama for first-time freshmen requires an online application, a $35 application fee, and an official high school transcript. The university has a test-optional admission policy for students with a 2.25 or higher high school GPA. Students with a high school GPA between 2.00-2.24 must submit an official ACT or SAT score. For automatic admission, students must have a 2.00 high school GPA and an 18 ACT or 940 SAT.

After being admitted to the university and completing required coursework, students must apply for admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP). TEP admission requirements include: completion of 48 semester hours of coursework, a minimum overall GPA of 2.75 for unconditional admission (2.50-2.74 for conditional), successful completion of the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators tests (Reading 156, Writing 162, Mathematics 150) OR an ACT composite score of 21 or higher, a cleared Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE) background check, proof of liability insurance, a passing score on the TEP interview, and completion of the TEP application.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: This program of study is designed for students who want to become secondary education teachers of Biology in middle and high schools. The program combines coursework in biology, education, and general studies to provide students with a strong foundation in the biological sciences and the pedagogical skills necessary to effectively teach biology to adolescents. Students will learn about various biological topics, including cell biology, genetics, ecology, evolution, and human anatomy and physiology, as well as educational theories and practices, classroom management, and curriculum development. Graduates of this program will be eligible for secondary education teacher certification in Biology in Alabama and other states.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Business Marketing (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All applicants must provide proof of English proficiency. An applicant may prove proficiency by providing an official score report from one of the approved standardized tests: TOEFL 61 iBT (or 500 PBT), IELTS 5.5, PTE Academic 46, Duolingo English Test 95, or successful completion of ELS Language Center Level 112.
Requirements: Students applying for admission must submit an application for admission and an official high school transcript. For Unconditional Admission, students may be admitted with a 2.25 or higher high school GPA; UNA is Test-Optional for students applying for admission with at least a 2.25 high school GPA. For Conditional Admission, students with a 2.00-2.24 high school GPA and a 16 ACT composite or 880 SAT total (ERW+M) may be admitted.
Department: Sanders College of Business and Technology and College of Education and Human Sciences
Fees: In-State: $5,100/Semester or $10,200/Year. Out-of-State: $10,200/Semester or $20,400/Year. (Based on 2023-2024 rates for 12-18 credit hours per semester).
Description: The Business Marketing (Secondary Education) program at the University of North Alabama prepares students to teach business and marketing subjects in secondary schools (grades 6-12). This program combines coursework in business administration, marketing, and education, ensuring graduates have both strong content knowledge and pedagogical skills. Students will gain expertise in areas such as marketing principles, business law, entrepreneurship, finance, and instructional strategies for diverse learners. The curriculum is designed to meet state licensure requirements for secondary education teachers in Alabama and other states with reciprocal agreements. Graduates are well-prepared for careers as business and marketing educators, as well as roles in business training and development.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
CollegeApplicationFee: In-State: $5,100/Semester or $10,200/Year. Out-of-State: $10,200/Semester or $20,400/Year. (Based on 2023-2024 rates for 12-18 credit hours per semester).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Chemistry (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: Evidence of English proficiency is required of all applicants from countries where English is not the native language. This can be demonstrated by one of the following: TOEFL: minimum score of 500 (PBT) or 61 (iBT); IELTS: minimum score of 5.5; PTE Academic: minimum score of 46; Duolingo: minimum score of 95; Completion of the UNA English as a Second Language Program (ESL); ELS Language Center: completion of Level 112.
Requirements: First-time freshmen who have not previously enrolled at a college or university must submit an application for admission, a $35 application fee, and an official high school transcript. The University of North Alabama is a test-optional institution, and freshmen applicants are not required to submit an ACT/SAT score for admission consideration.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S. in Education) program in Secondary Education prepares students to teach in grades 6-12 in various subject areas. Students completing the program are eligible for Alabama Class B Professional Educator Certification in their teaching field. The program requires students to complete general studies coursework, professional studies courses, and specialized courses in their teaching field (concentration). The specific requirements for each teaching field are outlined below.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) and the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges (SACSCOC)
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $1,000 to $8,500 per year, up to the full cost of tuition.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Collaborative Teacher (K-6)
Requirements:
Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) is a separate process from admission to the University. TEP admission is required before a candidate can enroll in any upper-level (300 or 400) professional studies courses. Requirements for Admission to the Teacher Education Program are:
- A grade of C or better in EN 111, EN 112, COM 201, and in all professional studies and teaching field courses.
- An overall 2.75 GPA (including transfer work), a 2.75 GPA in the area of professional studies, and a 2.75 GPA in the teaching field.
- Completion of a background check through the State of Alabama.
- Proof of professional liability insurance.
- A passing score on the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP).
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Collaborative Teacher (K-6) program is designed to provide candidates with the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to work with students who have diverse learning needs. Candidates will learn to plan and implement individualized instructional strategies based on student needs, collaborate with general education teachers and other professionals, and use data to make instructional decisions. The program emphasizes inclusive practices and prepares candidates to teach in a variety of settings.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Early Childhood Education (P-3)
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English proficiency. This can be demonstrated by achieving one of the following: a minimum score of 61 on the internet-based TOEFL (iBT), a minimum score of 5.5 on the IELTS, a minimum score of 46 on the PTE Academic, a minimum score of 95 on the Duolingo English Test, or successful completion of the ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements:
To be eligible for admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP), the candidate must have: 
1. A minimum of 48 semester hours earned at a regionally accredited institution, including all required general studies and teaching field courses appropriate for the first four semesters of the chosen program of study. At least one semester must have been completed at UNA. 
2. Completed with a grade of C or better in the appropriate introductory professional education course sequence: ED 299, ED 381, EED 361, or EED 371; EN 111, EN 112; COM 201; MA 110, or a higher-level mathematics course; and at least one science course from biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics. 
3. Earned an overall GPA of 2.75 on all coursework attempted at all institutions attended. 
4. Earned a passing score on all parts of the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP), or received an ACT score of 22 or higher on the English, Reading, and Math sections of the ACT with a Composite score of 24 or higher on one test administration, or received an SAT score of 1190 or higher with a score of 550 or higher on the Evidence-Based Reading and Writing and a score of 550 or higher on Math on one test administration. 
5. Completed a successful background check in accordance with requirements of the Alabama State Department of Education.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Early Childhood Education (P-3) program prepares candidates to educate young children in public and private schools and agencies. Teacher candidates seeking the B.S.Ed. in Early Childhood Education (P-3) will complete courses in foundational studies, general studies, teaching fields, and professional studies. The Early Childhood Education (P-3) program prepares students to work with children from birth through third grade, and leads to Alabama Class B professional educator certification.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Elementary Education (K-6)
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate a sufficient level of skill with the English language. This can be met by ONE of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT score of 61 or PBT score of 500; International English Language Testing System (IELTS) score of 5.5; Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic score of 46; Duolingo English Test score of 90; or successful completion of level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: General freshman admission to the university is test-optional for students with a 2.75 or higher high school GPA. For those submitting scores, unconditional admission requires a minimum 2.50 GPA and 18 ACT or 960 SAT score. Conditional admission requires a minimum 2.00 GPA and 16 ACT or 880 SAT score. After admission to the university, students must apply for admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP). TEP requirements include: an overall GPA of 2.75 on a minimum of 48 semester hours, completion of specific general education courses with a 'C' or higher, a passing score on the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators Tests, a passing score on the departmental writing assessment, and a clear background check.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Fees: Undergraduate (12-18 hours): In-State: $5,400 per semester; Out-of-State: $10,800 per semester.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education in Elementary Education (K-6) prepares individuals to teach in Alabama elementary schools. Individuals who successfully complete the program requirements, pass all required Praxis examinations, and meet all requirements for teacher certification, including background clearance, will be recommended for Class B certification in Elementary Education (K-6). Candidates for admission to the Elementary Education (K-6) program must meet the general requirements for admission to the UNA Teacher Education Program and must have an overall GPA of 2.75 on all coursework attempted. Specific information about the requirements for admission to the Teacher Education Program is found in the Education section of the catalog. The program is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP)
CostPerCredit: In-State: $360 per credit hour; Out-of-State: $720 per credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, academic scholarships for freshmen range from $3,000 to $8,000 per year.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in English Language Arts (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: To be considered for admission, international students must provide evidence of English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT with a score of 61 (or 500 on the PBT), IELTS with a score of 5.5, PTE Academic with a score of 46, or Duolingo English Test with a score of 95. Successful completion of ELS Language Center’s Level 112 also meets this requirement.
Requirements: Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) is prerequisite to enrollment in all professional studies courses other than ED 299, ED 381, ED 381W, and EDU 300W. Requirements for unconditional admission to TEP are: 1. Completion of ED 299, ED 381/381W, and EDU 300W with grades of C or better. 2. Minimum overall grade point average of 2.75. 3. Passing score on the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP). 4. Completion of a background clearance according to requirements of the Alabama State Department of Education. 5. Approval of the TEP admissions committee.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education degree in English Language Arts (Secondary Education) is designed to prepare students for teaching English/Language Arts, including literature, composition, and language, in grades six through twelve. Students completing the program will meet all requirements for a Class B Professional Educator Certificate in English Language Arts (6-12) issued by the Alabama State Department of Education.
Accredidation: The University of North Alabama Professional Educator Preparation Programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The programs are also approved by the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE).
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by scholarship, with awards ranging from $4,000 to full tuition, room, board, fees, and books.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Family and Consumer Sciences (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English proficiency by providing an official score report from one of the tests listed below: TOEFL iBT minimum score of 61, TOEFL PBT minimum score of 500, IELTS Academic minimum overall score of 5.5, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic minimum overall score of 46, Duolingo English Test (DET) minimum overall score of 90, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 109 English for Academic Purposes.
Requirements:
Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) is required. To be eligible for admission to the TEP, a candidate must meet the following requirements:
1. Successfully complete a minimum of 48 semester hours of coursework.
2. Earn a minimum grade of C in EH 101, EH 102, COM 201, and all professional studies and teaching field courses attempted.
3. Successfully complete ED 299 or ED 299W.
4. Possess a minimum overall grade point average (GPA) of 2.75 on all coursework attempted at all institutions.
5. Successfully complete and pass the background check process through the ALSDE approved vendor.
6. Possess a valid ALSDE-issued Substitute Teacher License.
7. Provide evidence of professional liability insurance.
8. Complete an application for admission to the TEP.
9. Qualify for admission based on one of the following options: Pass all subtests of the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators test (Reading, Writing, and Mathematics); OR Have an ACT composite score of 21 or higher; OR Have a bachelor's or higher degree from a regionally accredited institution.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education in Family and Consumer Sciences (Secondary Education) prepares students to teach Family and Consumer Sciences (FCS) in secondary schools (grades 6-12). The program includes professional studies and content courses in family and consumer sciences. FCS content areas include food and nutrition, family relations, human development, housing and interior design, and clothing and textiles. Upon completion of the program, students are eligible for Class B (bachelor's level) teacher certification in Family and Consumer Sciences (secondary education) in Alabama. All students pursuing Class B teacher certification must meet current certification requirements as specified by the Alabama State Board of Education (ALSBE). These requirements include specific passing scores on the appropriate PRAXIS II Subject Assessment(s) and the PRAXIS II Principles of Learning and Teaching (PLT) exam. Students must also meet other certification requirements established by ALSBE.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in French (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English are required to demonstrate English proficiency. Proficiency can be demonstrated by meeting the minimum score on one of the following exams: TOEFL (PBT 500, CBT 173, iBT 61), IELTS (5.5), PTE Academic (46), Duolingo English Test (95), or completion of ELS Language Center Level 112 with a grade of at least B.
Requirements: Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) is a prerequisite to enrollment in any professional studies courses beyond the 300 level. Formal application for admission to the TEP is made as a part of EL 310W. Requirements for unconditional admission to TEP include: 1. A minimum 2.75 GPA overall, in teaching field, and in professional studies on a 4.0 scale on all work attempted at UNA and at other institutions; 2. A passing score on the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP), prescribed by the Alabama State Board of Education; 3. Must clear a state and federal fingerprint background check. Note: Suitability is determined by the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE). Any infractions must be cleared by the ALSDE prior to admission to the TEP; 4. Must purchase and maintain liability insurance throughout the clinical practice portions of the program; and 5. Successful completion of EL 310W with a grade of C or better.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education in French (Secondary Education) prepares candidates to teach French in secondary schools (grades 6-12). It provides a strong foundation in French language, literature, and culture, combined with professional education coursework and field experiences. Graduates are eligible for an Alabama Class B Professional Educator Certificate in French (grades 6-12) upon successful completion of all program requirements, including passing the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP) subject area assessment and edTPA performance assessment. The program includes general studies, teaching field requirements, and professional studies. Candidates are required to meet admission requirements to the professional teacher education program. For more information, please see the Professional Teacher Education Program Information section of this catalog. Admission to this program is competitive.
Accredidation: The programs in the Department of Teaching, Learning, and Leadership are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in General Science (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit evidence of English proficiency. This requirement can be satisfied with one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) minimum score of 61 iBT or 500 PBT; International English Language Testing System (IELTS) minimum score of 5.5; Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic minimum score of 46; Duolingo minimum score of 90; Completion of the ELS Language Centers Intensive English Program at Level 112.
Requirements: Initial admission to the university is test-optional for students with a high school GPA of 2.0 or higher. Specific to this degree, students must apply and be admitted to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) after completing at least 48 semester hours of coursework. TEP admission requires a minimum GPA of 2.75 (overall, in teaching field, and professional studies), completion of prerequisite general education courses, a passing score on the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP) basic skills assessment (currently the Praxis® Core tests), a successful TEP interview, a clear background check, and proof of professional liability insurance.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education degree with a major in General Science prepares students to teach in grades 6-12. The degree program includes course work in the natural sciences, mathematics, and professional studies in education, as well as a clinical internship. Graduates are eligible to pursue initial Alabama Class B Professional Educator Certification.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE).
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts range from $3,000/year to Full Tuition & Fees depending on the specific scholarship.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in General Social Science (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit evidence of proficiency in the English language. This can be met by submitting a satisfactory score on an English proficiency exam. Accepted exams and minimum scores include TOEFL iBT (61), TOEFL PBT (500), IELTS (5.5), PTE (46), or Duolingo (95). Successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112 also satisfies the requirement.
Requirements:
Admission to the Teacher Education Program is required. Requirements for admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) are:
1. Completion of an application for admission to the TEP.
2. Completion of a minimum of 48 semester hours of coursework.
3. A grade point average of at least 2.75 on a 4.00 scale on all coursework attempted (overall), in professional studies, and in the teaching field(s).
4. Completion of EN 111, EN 112, COM 201, and the General Studies math course required for the major with a grade of C or better in each.
5. Completion of ED 299 or EED 299 with a grade of C or better.
6. A passing score on the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP) as required by the Alabama State Department of Education.
7. A satisfactory background check as required by the Alabama State Department of Education.
8. Proof of professional liability insurance.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Accredidation: Approved by the Alabama State Department of Education and accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) at the initial and advanced levels.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Geography (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide evidence of English proficiency.
Requirements:
Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) is required for enrollment in all upper-level professional studies courses. The requirements for admission to TEP are:
1. Completion of 48 semester hours of coursework.
2. Minimum overall grade point average (GPA) of 2.75 on all coursework attempted.
3. Completion of EN 111, EN 112, COM 201, and the general education mathematics requirement(s) for the student's major with a grade of C or better.
4. Background clearance through the ALSDE.
5. Proof of professional liability insurance.
6. A passing score on the basic skills assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP). An ACT composite score of 21 or higher may be used to meet the basic skills assessment requirement.
7. Completion of TEP application.
8. A successful interview with the TEP Admissions Committee.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in German (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of proficiency through one of the following: a minimum TOEFL score of 500 (PBT) or 61 (iBT), a minimum IELTS score of 5.5, a minimum PTE-A score of 46, a minimum Duolingo score of 90, or successful completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
Admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP) requires the following:

1. Completion of a minimum of 48 semester hours of coursework.
2. A minimum overall grade point average of 2.75 on all coursework OR a 3.0 on the last 32 semester hours attempted at UNA.
3. A minimum composite score of 21 on the ACT (or 1060 SAT) OR passing scores on all three sections of the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators Tests (Core) in Reading (156), Writing (162) and Mathematics (150).
4. Completion of EN 111, EN 112, COM 201, a literature sequence, a history sequence, and the general education mathematics requirement with a grade of C or higher in each course.
5. Satisfactory completion of an interview with a committee of at least three members of the College of Education and Human Sciences faculty who hold teaching certificates.
6. Satisfactory results of a background check in accordance with Alabama Code 2002, Title 16, Chapter 22A, Section 6.
7. Proof of liability insurance.
8. An approved application to TEP on file in the Office of Student Success and Certification.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education degree in German (6-12) prepares students to teach German in secondary schools (grades 6-12). The program combines a strong foundation in German language, literature, and culture with professional education coursework and practical experiences necessary for Alabama teacher certification. Graduates will be equipped to foster linguistic proficiency and cultural understanding in their future students.
Accredidation: The UNA Professional Education Programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in History (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All international students must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be demonstrated by one of the following: TOEFL: 61 iBT or 500 PBT; IELTS: 5.5; PTE: 46; Duolingo: 95; ELS: Completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
All secondary education programs require admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP). TEP admission requirements include:
1. An application for admission to the TEP submitted through the Tk20 system.
2. A minimum overall GPA of 2.75 on all work attempted at UNA and on all work attempted at other institutions.
3. Successful completion of EN 111, EN 112, COM 201, a general studies history, and a general studies mathematics course, all of which must be applicable to the student’s program of study.
4. A grade of C or better in EN 111, EN 112, and COM 201.
5. Successful completion of ED 299 or ECE 210 with a grade of C or better.
6. A qualifying score on the basic skills component of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP). Options include a) ACT: A composite score of 20 with a 20 or higher on the English subject area test and a 20 or higher on the mathematics subject area test; b) SAT: A score of 1030 on the mathematics and critical reading sections with a score of 500 or higher on both the mathematics and critical reading sections; or c) Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators tests: Reading 156, Writing 162, and Mathematics 150.
7. A satisfactory background clearance based on the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE) background check requirements.
8. Evidence of professional dispositions as evaluated by faculty and cooperating teachers in ED 299 or ECE 210.
9. Successful completion of an admission interview.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education in History (Secondary Education) program prepares students to teach history and social studies to students in grades 6-12. This program develops subject matter competence in history and the related social studies, knowledge of the appropriate teaching methods, and extensive experience in clinical settings prior to the final internship. The program leads to Class B Teacher Certification in History (6-12) in Alabama.
Accredidation: All teacher education programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Mathematics (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All students must demonstrate English proficiency before they can be admitted to the university. Students may meet this requirement through one of the following: a minimum score of 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT) or 500 on the paper-based test (pBT); a minimum score of 5.5 on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS); a minimum score of 46 on the Pearson Test of English (PTE); a minimum score of 90 on the Duolingo test of English proficiency; successful completion of Level 112 of the ELS Language Centers (ELS) program.
Requirements:
To be eligible for unconditional admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP), which is a requirement for this degree, a candidate must: 
1. Have an overall GPA of at least 2.75 on a 4.0 scale for unconditional admission or a GPA of 2.50-2.74 on a 4.0 scale for conditional admission. The GPA is calculated on all coursework taken at all institutions.
2. Complete at least 48 semester hours of coursework.
3. Complete EN 111, EN 112, and COM 201 with a grade of C or better.
4. Complete the General Studies mathematics requirement with a grade of C or better.
5. Complete ED 299 or EED 299 or SE 299 with a grade of C or better.
6. Receive a passing score on the Basic Skills Assessment of the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP). Effective September 1, 2017, candidates must provide documentation of passing scores on the ACT® Reading (22), English (22), and Mathematics (22) subtests.
7. Provide documentation of a clear background check through the designated background check agency for the College of Education and Human Sciences.
8. Provide evidence of liability insurance from the student chapter of the Alabama Education Association (AEA) or other approved source.
9. Complete an application for admission to TEP.
10. Receive a favorable recommendation from the TEP Admissions Committee.
Department: College of Education and Human Sciences
Description: The Secondary Education: Mathematics program is designed for students who desire to teach mathematics in middle schools (grades 4-8) and high schools (grades 9-12). The program leads to a Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) degree and eligibility for teacher certification in Alabama. The curriculum emphasizes a deep understanding of mathematical concepts, pedagogical strategies specific to mathematics education, and practical teaching experience through field placements and student teaching.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Music-Choral (P-12) (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: All students are required to be proficient in English. International applicants must submit an official score report from one of the following English proficiency examinations: TOEFL PBT: 500; TOEFL IBT: 61; IELTS: 5.5; PTE: 46; Duolingo: 95; ELS: 109.
Department: College of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education (BSE) degree in Music (P-12) (Secondary Education) is offered for those students who desire to teach Music in grades P-12. The BSE in Music (P-12) (Secondary Education) is a curriculum approved by the Alabama State Department of Education and meets the standards of the National Association of Schools of Music. Students must successfully complete a program of study consisting of 120-128 semester hours with a major in Music (P-12) (Secondary Education). For admission to the Teacher Education program, students must meet UNA standards for admission to teacher education programs as defined by the College of Education and Human Sciences. For graduation, students must meet College of Education and Human Sciences, Department of Music, and UNA requirements. The BSE in Music (P-12) (Secondary Education) program offers concentrations in Choral and Instrumental. Students must apply for admission to the Teacher Education Program after earning 48 semester hours with a minimum 2.75 GPA. Students must be fully admitted to Teacher Education prior to enrolling in professional studies courses. Additionally, students must earn a minimum grade of "C" or better in all professional studies courses and major field courses. EnglishScore: Proof of English proficiency is required of all applicants whose native language is not English. Requirements: The University of North Alabama has a test-optional admission policy. Applicants may submit ACT/SAT scores or choose not to. For Test-Optional Admission, a minimum 2.25 cumulative high school GPA is required, and applications undergo a holistic review. Description: The Bachelor of Science in Education (B.S.Ed.) degree in Physics (Secondary Education) prepares students for careers as secondary school physics teachers. The program provides a comprehensive understanding of physics principles and pedagogical methods specific to teaching physics at the secondary level. Students will engage in rigorous coursework covering classical mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and optics, alongside professional studies in education focused on curriculum development, instructional strategies, classroom management, and student assessment relevant to diverse learning environments. Through supervised field experiences and student teaching, candidates will gain practical skills in designing and delivering effective physics instruction, fostering scientific inquiry, and promoting critical thinking among high school students. Graduates will be eligible for secondary professional educator certification in physics in Alabama and are well-prepared to make significant contributions to science education.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Education in Visual Arts (P-12) (Secondary Education)
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit evidence of proficiency in the English language. Acceptable evidence includes a minimum score of 500 on the paper-based TOEFL (PBT) or 61 on the Internet-based test (iBT); a minimum score of 5.5 on the IELTS; a minimum score of 46 on the PTE Academic; a minimum score of 95 on the Duolingo English Test; or completion of ELS Language Centers Level 109.
Requirements:
Admission to the University of North Alabama does not include admission to the Teacher Education Program (TEP). Candidates seeking certification must meet the following requirements to be admitted to the TEP.
1. A minimum of 48 semester hours of credit earned.
2. A minimum grade point average of 2.75 on a 4.00 scale for all coursework attempted and in each of the following areas: teaching field, professional studies and overall.
3. A qualifying score on the basic skills component of the state prescribed test (ACT score of 20 or higher on the English, Reading, and Math sections; or passing scores on all three sections of the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators test). Scores must be on file in the Certification Office (501 Willsingham Hall) prior to admission to TEP. For current passing scores for the Praxis Core tests, visit the Alabama State Department of Education website.
4. Successful completion of an interview with a minimum of two full-time faculty from the College of Education and Human Sciences.
5. Successful completion of the following courses with a grade of C or better: ED 299; and EED 361W or SED 372W; and COM 201; and EN 111 and EN 112; and MA 110 or higher.
6. Proof of professional liability insurance. The student membership in the Alabama Education Association includes the required insurance. This insurance must be kept current throughout the program.
7. A clear background check based on an official criminal history background check through the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE).
8. A grade of C or better in all professional studies and teaching field courses.
